Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Story: My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Call Mom and Dad.” Every Sunday evening, I set aside time to talk to them, to share my week and hear about theirs. It’s our ritual, and I know how much it means to them, especially since I moved out. But as I glanced at the clock, my laptop chimed with a calendar alert—our team’s final project meeting was about to start. This was the last chance to voice concerns before the big launch, and my manager had stressed the importance of everyone’s input. I could already picture my parents waiting by the phone, expecting my call, while my team would be watching for my name to pop up in the meeting. My heart pounded as I weighed the disappointment in my parents’ voices against the pressure from my colleagues. I stared at my phone, torn, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which expectation I would have to let down.
